criticReviews.excerpt: “ ‘Here Lies Love’ bets that glamour can make up for narrative — or, rather, that in a show about the dangers of political demagogy, glamour itself is the narrative. It’s a case of form follows function into the fire. We are drawn to cultural and political excitement in much the same, often dangerous way.”

criticReviews.author: Allison Considine
criticReviews.excerpt: “Audience members whose knowledge of Imelda Marcos is limited to the fact that she owned 3,000 pairs of shoes will only leave with a partial understanding of this violent period. The musical has no book, and the punchy songs paint broad strokes of the 60-year history... Still, this rollicking, form-breaking musical party is well worth an RSVP.”

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: “Our complicity with such cycles of populist fervor—whether, depending on your ticket, as spectators from a safe distance or as extras in a mob scene—is the loudly beating heart of ‘Here Lies Love,’ a party that hides a mordant critique of civilization and its discotheques.”

criticReviews.author: Jackson McHenry
criticReviews.excerpt: “...the crowd itself is ‘Here Lies Love’s’ main character, this mass of people looking to be appeased by a good performance, no matter who’s singing the political karaoke. The show ends with democracy, but it has a wary relationship with the masses. The thought may be that, lured by a beat good enough, they’ll dance along to anything.”

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: “What may be most remarkable about ‘Here Lies Love’ is how deftly it pivots from the celebratory and even sentimental presentation of Imelda’s rise to the inevitably condemnatory”

criticReviews.author: Greg Evans
criticReviews.excerpt: “The real pull of ‘Here Lies Love’ is the staging, with a malleable performance space, an audience herded to and fro, and cast members finding perches throughout the venue.”

criticReviews.author: Chris Jones
criticReviews.excerpt: “You can sit and observe the show all around you or you can pay to hit the orchestra floor and party with the Marcoses. Whee!...At no more than 100 minutes long, ‘Here Lies Love’ never over-indulges nor does it lose the audience’s attention for a moment. “

criticReviews.author: Naveen Kumar
criticReviews.excerpt: “Byrne and Fatboy Slim’s sung-through score is the star of the 90-minute production, a hypnotic churn of synth beats, funky rhythms and pop momentum that aims squarely for the pelvis.”

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: “it is a welcome change that the seven autistic characters in ‘How to Dance in Ohio’ are presented, without condescension, as young adults a lot like most others, albeit with unusual gifts and challenges. That they are also played by autistic performers makes the feel-good show, which opened on Sunday at the Belasco Theater, more than a first: It’s a milestone.”

criticReviews.author: Joe Dziemianowicz
criticReviews.excerpt: “At the heart of the wonderfully performed but uneven musical ‘How to Dance in Ohio’ beats a reality for its key characters that is at once simple and profound...in the end, this worthwhile musical finds the steps to an upbeat last dance.”

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: “All of the actors playing autistic people publicly identify as autistic themselves; they’re also all making their Broadway debuts, and while some are more experienced than others—Pearce, with his expansively emotional voice, is a ringer—they all make winsome impressions.”

criticReviews.author: Jackson McHenry
criticReviews.excerpt: “It’s a credit to ‘How to Dance in Ohio’s’ cast that they deliver compelling performances, even when their material gets rote and didactic...If we’re here to meet these characters who aren’t going to be stand-ins for generalized traits, let’s really spend the time to get to know them all.”

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: “ ‘How to Dance in Ohio’ is certainly less raw and dispassionately observed than the movie. But this is not a documentary but a Broadway musical comedy, and as such engineered to meet the requirements of most popular entries in the genre today: uplift, sweetness, rainbow endings for all.”

criticReviews.author: Greg Evans
criticReviews.excerpt: “One of the things ‘How To Dance In Ohio’ gets so splendidly right is the easy comfort with diversity these young people with autism are graced, as if they’ve long ago made peace with the very concept of outsiderdom.”

criticReviews.author: Frank Rizzo
criticReviews.excerpt: “Under director Sammi Cannold’s staging, the actors perform with verve, commitment and authenticity — and, in a few cases, show some real star power.”

criticReviews.author: David Cote
criticReviews.excerpt: “Generically staged by Sammi Cannold, ‘How to Dance in Ohio’ was clearly made with love and will touch some hearts—on the spectrum or not—but feels synthetic and patchy when not outright tacky.”

criticReviews.author: Thom Geier
criticReviews.excerpt: "...a sui generis multidisciplinary marvel that suggests new possibilities"

criticReviews.author: Mason Pilevsky
criticReviews.excerpt: Truly in awe of the duality and interconnectedness of the pulse of Illinoise.

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: "a mysterious and deeply moving dance-musical"

criticReviews.author: Amelia Merrill
criticReviews.excerpt: "A few instances of more heavy-handed literalism are sprinkled through the piece"

criticReviews.author: Sara Holdren
criticReviews.excerpt: "Beyond...its few brief stumbles, Illinoise achieves a holistic transcendence."

criticReviews.author: Gloria Oladipo
criticReviews.excerpt: "Drury and Peck have crafted something cinematic"

criticReviews.author: Victor Gluck
criticReviews.excerpt: "Justin Peck’s evening length ballet...has the energy of Jerome Robbins’ 'Fancy Free'"

criticReviews.author: Jonathan Mandell
criticReviews.excerpt: "It's extraordinary, it's queer, it's often thrilling"

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: “Lempicka doesn’t have the craft...to make its title character a relatable modern woman"

criticReviews.author: Gillian Russo
criticReviews.excerpt: "a captivating portrait of an artist's life and loves"

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: "They have what the musical lacks: a clear and compelling aesthetic."

criticReviews.author: Sara Holdren
criticReviews.excerpt: "...while there are sparks of exuberance in the show, they don’t come from its center."

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: "Visually, the show is a hodgepodge."

criticReviews.author: Frank Rizzo
criticReviews.excerpt: "Eden Espinosa...brings both luminosity and strength to her powerful performance"

criticReviews.author: Philip Kennicott
criticReviews.excerpt: "An artist with a big, messy life gets a big, messy musical"

criticReviews.author: Johnny Oleksinski
criticReviews.excerpt: "Painter musical is an epic wreck"

criticReviews.author: Elisabeth Vincentelli
criticReviews.excerpt: “This timidity is but one example of the ways in which the show comes up short, both as a feminist text and as a tribute to Spears’s songbook — and, yes, her life. The last thing her fans might have expected from a Britney Spears musical is dutiful conventionality.”

criticReviews.author: Gillian Russo
criticReviews.excerpt: “The dance is truly what makes ‘Once Upon a One More Time’ worth the price of admission...also ultimately urges us not only to be willing to change the stories we tell and be open to new ideas, but also that sometimes, we must pass the pen to new writers to tell their stories themselves. That message has continued relevance — if anything, it's continually stronger than yesterday.”

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: “Simard is delicious; the rest of the show, if you turn off your brain, is merely yummy in a candy-coated way. That’s not nothing: ‘Once Upon a One More Time’ is a well-assembled and entertaining diversion...Musicals are capable of more ambitious roles than merely carrying Spears.”

criticReviews.author: Jackson McHenry
criticReviews.excerpt: “It’s a fun enough concert, though not worth sitting through two hours and 30 minutes of a dull musical to get there.”

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: “The musical’s primary assets are its splendid cast and the silly smartness of the integration of song and story. Which brings to mind the splendid, silly and smart performance of Jennifer Simard in the role of Cinderella’s stepmother...Ms. Simard, is one of Broadway’s unsung, or undersung, treasures, and her performance alone brings sufficient pleasure to make this trip to Britney-land worth a visit.”

criticReviews.author: Greg Evans
criticReviews.excerpt: “The wish-come-true of ’Once Upon a One More Time’ is that it lifts without apology or even a slight blush...To spoil the plot beyond this would be unfair, even though you’ll likely see most of the twists and turns coming, or at least predict the overall story arc.”

criticReviews.author: New York Daily News
criticReviews.excerpt: “The truly awful ‘Once Upon a One More Time,’...is not that musical. Instead, it tries to cash in on the repetitive fashion of the moralistic musical moment and uses Spears’ songs as a way to critique and deconstruct ‘problematic’ fairy tales.

criticReviews.author: New York Daily News
criticReviews.excerpt: “To use the Britney Spears catalog as the material for a musical preaching feminist enlightenment is, to put it mildly, a stretch.”

criticReviews.author: Elisabeth Vincentelli
criticReviews.excerpt: "While the dialogue has occasional pop, it’s the performances that keep the show rolling"

criticReviews.author: Gillian Russo
criticReviews.excerpt: "Director Gordon Greenberg’s production is eager to sweep you up in its bright lights"

criticReviews.author: Regina Robbins
criticReviews.excerpt: "Squeeze your memories into spandex and get ready to turn back the clock."

criticReviews.author: Jackson McHenry
criticReviews.excerpt: "The Heart of Rock and Roll is the funniest new musical of the season"

criticReviews.author: Chris Jones
criticReviews.excerpt: "...funny, unpretentious ’80s fun"

criticReviews.author: Frank Rizzo
criticReviews.excerpt: "Humor and brightness is what fuels this engine"

criticReviews.author: Kenji Fujishima
criticReviews.excerpt: "...I came out feeling buzzed, entertained…and slightly ashamed"

criticReviews.author: David Barbour
criticReviews.excerpt: Stop the presses! The headline news of the day is The Heart of Rock and Roll is...not bad.

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: "In the two-man, 20-character skit of a show that opened Thursday evening on Broadway, the jokes are abundant, interchangeable and lightweight: comedy as packing peanuts."

criticReviews.author: Joe Dziemianowicz
criticReviews.excerpt: “The show is a roughly 2-hour sketch – one that’s clever and filled with laughs but too long and overstuffed to ward off diminishing returns. Still, the production provides a prime showcase for the talents of Josh Gad and Andrew Rannells”

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: "Affection is the key that opens the show’s comedy: As ridiculous as Doug and Bud may be, you feel for these guys and even root for them. As stupid as their historical musical may be, you can’t deny that they’ve got heart."

criticReviews.author: Sara Holdren
criticReviews.excerpt: "Like the art it’s satirizing, it’s a genre that can sometimes feel a little dippy and indulgent, but at its best it’s both outrageously funny and strangely, sweetly sublime...Rannells and Gad are wonderfully matched and, it appears, having a real blast with each other. Their comic timing is wetsuit tight, their chemistry indisputable, their energy manic but precise and, crucially, unflagging."

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: "Even at a fairly pacey two hours the fun eventually turns to wheel-spinning, since the central gag—the ludicrous mismatch between content and form—is established from the start and then merely elaborated."

criticReviews.author: Frank Rizzo
criticReviews.excerpt: "The real fun, however — and there is much of it — lies in simply watching Gad and Rannells run riot, riff with each other, play with the audience, and just have a grand old time once again playing sweet, deluded dreamers...In the end, it’s not 'Gutenberg' the show but rather this odd coupling of comedic pals, both on stage and off, that delights. Hats off to them."

criticReviews.author: David Cote
criticReviews.excerpt: " 'Gutenberg!' is not designed to be anyone’s gateway musical or inspire a career in that impossible, flop-filled field, but it’s firmly imprinted on my heart, sans serif."

criticReviews.author: Peter Marks
criticReviews.excerpt: "Brown and King have packed the show with numbers that manage to be both entertaining and as clunky as a ’67 station wagon. And composed a piece that might be a bit more fitting in a cabaret than in a Broadway theater. That is, of course, until you secure the services of the cutest couple on Broadway."

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: CRITIC’S PICK: “Maria Friedman’s unsparing direction and a thrillingly fierce central performance by Jonathan Groff have given the show the hard shell it lacked. Now heartbreaking in the poignant sense only, ‘Merrily’ has been found in the dark.”

criticReviews.author: Joe Dziemianowicz
criticReviews.excerpt: “You’re going to want to preserve the riches flowing throughout this hurts-so-good musical about growing up and growing apart.”

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: “Friedman’s production meets the audience halfway, and a Broadway audience today just might be able to make up the difference as it couldn’t in 1981. Cross your fingers: It might finally be ’Merrily’s’ time.”

criticReviews.author: Sara Holdren
criticReviews.excerpt: “A central trio as sensitive and superb as this one doesn’t just make ’Merrily’ more moving; it makes it much more fun. It even adds a faint glimmer of something resembling hope...With their irresistible energy and chemistry, Mendez, Groff, and Radcliffe lift ’Merrily’ up, yet keep it grounded with real, apparent affection and emotional heft. They are the ones reviving the play, by revealing and jump-starting its heart.”

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: “The production shines a bright and welcome spotlight on a Sondheim score that has long been cherished by aficionados of his work...With this Broadway revival, sure to be the hottest ticket of the fall season, and perhaps the spring, too, Ms. Friedman and her cast and collaborators have ensured that Sondheim’s achievement will garner the wider popular appreciation it deserves.”

criticReviews.author: Greg Evans
criticReviews.excerpt: “Not that this new production of ’Merrily’ completely fills in and smoothes out the musical’s legendary potholes, but it certainly helps us step around them without too much effort or frustration. You’d be hard-pressed to imagine a better ’Merrily We Roll Along’.”

criticReviews.author: Trish Deitch
criticReviews.excerpt: “What makes the musical hard for first-time audiences is the fact that it’s like a jigsaw puzzle doled out one piece at a time, so you don’t see a complete picture until the last piece is placed and the show is over...That’s why ‘Merrily We Roll Along’ is art and not comfortably commercial theater.”

criticReviews.author: Peter Marks
criticReviews.excerpt: “Ideally, this Broadway incarnation will be both a hit and a reflection of the higher aspirations of musical theater. It’s even tighter, funnier and more touching than what Friedman staged off-Broadway. So much ingenuity. So much joyful creativity. So much for audiences to savor.”

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: CRITIC’S PICK:“The key to the comedy is not after all replication but individuation. The Pythons were each their own kind of oddball, and the bits are only funny with fresh bite...For all its nostalgia value, and its endless verbal invention, ‘Spamalot,’...has a very vexed soul.”

criticReviews.author: Gillian Russo
criticReviews.excerpt: “This Broadway revival, ‘Spamalot's’ first, feels like a proclamation that the musical's heyday is not dead yet, either...The other strength of ‘Spamalot’ is that it gives every one of its principal cast members a chance to shine. And shine they do. “

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: “Rhodes’s cast of show-tune pros is highly capable, and the show’s laughter now seems more like it’s coming from inside the Broadway house. It’s a true ensemble effort...In this company of men, however, it is a woman who really dazzles: Leslie Rodriguez Kritzer as the sword-bestowing Lady of the Lake...It’s in the Lady of the Lake’s spotlight moments, the show’s biggest departure from the nearly all-male Grail, that Spamalot comes into its own most effectively and takes flight—not as an African swallow, capable of carrying significant weight, or merely as a parrot, possibly dead, but as what it is: a lark.”

criticReviews.author: Sara Holdren
criticReviews.excerpt: “It’s true that there’s a sugar-high quality to ‘Spamalot’: By the end, your teeth are buzzing from the sheer multitude of sparkles and crescendos. But there’s also an embrace of its form’s inherent absurdity that feels almost existential, and thereby true to Python.”

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: “The production is so richly stocked with prime talent that there isn’t a smidgen of a lull in the proceedings.”

criticReviews.author: Greg Evans
criticReviews.excerpt: “Perhaps most satisfying about ’Spamalot’ is how it differs from other movie-to-stage adaptations in landing every punchline even for those who know what’s coming.”

criticReviews.author: Naveen Kumar
criticReviews.excerpt: “The production’s overdesign is a symptom of the broader problem, which is a lack of ingenuity in favor of sheer excess. It is a paradox of throwing money onstage that it can easily come at the expense of creativity. There may be a way to reanimate ‘Spamalot,’ and for Monty Python’s random surrealism to infect a new generation and confront the current moment. But that grail is not to be found here.”

criticReviews.author: Peter Marks
criticReviews.excerpt: “This new ‘Spamalot’ arrives, beefed up, gussied up and yes, even funnier than in its birthing engagement earlier this year...the revival of the Tony-winning musical by Python great Eric Idle, with John Du Prez, brings joy to a land desperately short of guffaws and chuckles and snickers and giggles.”

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: "What I missed in the middle of all that overemphasis was some sense of humanity"

criticReviews.author: Joe Dziemianowicz
criticReviews.excerpt: "Tommy’s saga delivers a pointed and potent take on trauma, fame, and individuality"

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: "As musical theater, Tommy is limited. On its own terms, it’s often sensational."

criticReviews.author: Sara Holdren
criticReviews.excerpt: "There’s something exhilarating and also a little bizarre about Tommy"

criticReviews.author: Helen Shaw
criticReviews.excerpt: "The 1993 musical's already bizarre story...even less clear in Des McAnuff's reanimation"

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: "...brings an intoxicating energy to the story of a boy who survives trauma"

criticReviews.author: Trish Deitch
criticReviews.excerpt: "...this production of 'Tommy' is basically for old people, and not for a new generation"

criticReviews.author: Elisabeth Vincentelli
criticReviews.excerpt: "A new revival...feels like it takes place in the multiverse"

criticReviews.author: Maya Phillips
criticReviews.excerpt: “ 'The Wiz' is a pleasant, serviceable time at the theater"

criticReviews.author: Kyle Turner
criticReviews.excerpt: "musical revival celebrates a history of Black creativity and culture"

criticReviews.author: Jackson McHenry
criticReviews.excerpt: "...full of funk, R&B, gospel, and more, will still thrill and delight you."

criticReviews.author: Naveen Kumar
criticReviews.excerpt: "...this Oz comes across more like a playground than a coming-of-age purgatory"

criticReviews.author: Gloria Oladipo
criticReviews.excerpt: "The new Broadway revival is charming, but at the cost of a broader artistic vision"

criticReviews.author: Johnny Oleksinski
criticReviews.excerpt: "...the new revival...is not the dazzler that fans have waited so long for."

criticReviews.author: Lester Fabian Brathwaite
criticReviews.excerpt: "The Wiz is all about feeling...in complex times, its simple message rings loud and clear"

criticReviews.author: David Gordon
criticReviews.excerpt: "There’s no connection, no chemistry, no soul. "

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: “That teasing quality, though sometimes charming — and often, if you are a scaredy-cat, a relief from the hard-core jolts — is the giveaway that ‘Grey House’ should not be taken too seriously, regardless of its allusions to real-world horror of the past and present.”

criticReviews.author: Joe Dziemianowicz
criticReviews.excerpt: “One wishes the series of scenes built to a deeper, more full-scale sense of dread. In terms of fright nights, ’Grey House’ is entertaining, albeit middle of the road.”

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: " ''Grey Houe' is built around themes of guilt, expiation and retribution, but not very solidly—and as a spectator, you’re too busy puzzling out what is happening to think much about what it means...Amid such excellent atmospherics, you may not care when the play itself creaks."

criticReviews.author: Jackson McHenry
criticReviews.excerpt: “Once you get to huge Broadway houses, claustrophobia is harder to maintain... But it was also fun to see the production swing so hard at genre tropiness. If it doesn’t fully succeed on its own terms, it’s at least a solid reminder that terror is as worthy of drama as any other kind of spectacle.”

criticReviews.author: Dan Stahl
criticReviews.excerpt: "They’re frighteningly convincing, as are most of the ghoulish effects and all the performers. Joe Mantello directs one hell of a show."

criticReviews.author: Greg Evans
criticReviews.excerpt: “...a savvy tale that might be likened to a dark, lonely lake on a moonless night – scary enough on the surface, scarier still when one ponders what’s below the surface. There are some stretches that start to feel dull or repetitive, possibly the result of confusion as to what, exactly, is going on, but such moments fade with the next scream.”

criticReviews.author: Chris Jones
criticReviews.excerpt: “ ‘Grey House’ is trying to honor that unstinting parentage, despite the baked-in demands on a mostly young cast of kids, who give it all they’ve got. The show also has to whip up interest on a hot summer night. That’s not an easy combo, and you can see the strains it puts on the second half of the show, but much of worth gets unpacked here. Scarily so, to boot.”

criticReviews.author: A.D. Amorosi
criticReviews.excerpt: “The most haunted, haunting performance comes from Sophia Anne Caruso as Marlow...Cracking wise with aching vulnerability, Caruso is the insistent, irresistible heart of ‘Grey House’ and its sonorous death knell.”

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: “It’s hard to imagine what more one could make of an upbeat play about hoarding. The condition is not funny...In a disposable society, hostile to aging, in which anything or anyone no longer obviously useful belongs in the landfill, he believes in hanging on. His hoarding isn’t a condition, it’s a protest.”

criticReviews.author: Joe Dziemianowicz
criticReviews.excerpt: “The vintage board game Sorry! wasn't designed to be played alone. Leave it to Emmy winner Danny DeVito, who shines as the aimless widow Sam in ‘I Need That’, to turn the unlikely moment into a theatrical highlight that’s silly, sad, and, no joke, poetic.”

criticReviews.author: Will Gleason
criticReviews.excerpt: “DeVito is a star for a reason: His vulnerable, hilarious performance is a certifiable gem. If only this treasure weren’t so often lost in the piles that surround it.”

criticReviews.author: Sara Holdren
criticReviews.excerpt: “There’s a certain kind of numbness that sets in when you’re stuck in a theater and you realize that the characters up onstage are going to keep playing the same scene, over and over again, for the rest of the evening.”

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: “Absent high drama, the director, Moritz von Stuelpnagel massages the play’s turning points effectively...Mr. DeVito, a master of sharp jabs of sarcasm...buoys the play with his tangy ripostes, as when he feigns surrender...but in surprising ways Sam’s travails remind us that at least they can keep sadness and emptiness briefly at bay.”

criticReviews.author: Greg Evans
criticReviews.excerpt: “Clutter – physical, emotional – is the subject of Theresa Rebeck’s new Broadway play ‘I Need That’, a comedy-drama that stars Danny DeVito works mightily and with increasing futility to stuff with laughs and meaning.”

criticReviews.author: Trish Deitch
criticReviews.excerpt: “ ‘I Need That’ will prove satisfying for those looking to be entertained by DeVito and his daughter. He brings real joy and laughter, and there’s real value in that.”

criticReviews.author: David Cote
criticReviews.excerpt: “DeVito gets more mileage out of Sam than you’d expect from the page, performing with a loose, raffish panache...Funny pronunciation. Silly faces. Kooky obsessives behaving irrationally. It’s been the stuff of sitcoms for decades and popular for a reason. Still, when you put TV-level product on the Broadway stage, don’t be surprised if the audience talks back.”

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: CRITIC’S PICK: “The first 80 minutes of the 90-minute play...are a buffet of delights. Even David Zinn’s set for the beauty shop’s interior, once the grate is unlocked and lifted, receives entrance applause. From that moment on, the director, Whitney White, keeps the stage activated and the stories simmering at a happy bubble.”

criticReviews.author: Gillian Russo
criticReviews.excerpt: “Despite some narrative clunkiness, ’Jaja’ offers plenty to celebrate...It's a passionate portrayal of Black womanhood in Harlem and all the diverse experiences that encompasses. And it's a love letter to the artistry of hair braiding, a millennia-old form of artistry that allows its participants to express themselves even as they transform themselves. Much like theatre.”

criticReviews.author: Sara Holdren
criticReviews.excerpt: “Bioh has written a colorful, tactile, and caring work, letting us in on both the beauty of the braiding process...and the intense labor of it”

criticReviews.author: Chris Jones
criticReviews.excerpt: “ ‘Jaja’s’ is a comedy about life as it is lived in this place, about community, aspiration and entrepreneurship. Mostly, though, it’s a show about immigrants getting the job done, and having fun doing it, one braid at a time.”

criticReviews.author: Aramide Tinubu
criticReviews.excerpt: “ ‘Jaja’s African Hair Braiding’ celebrates business owners like Jaja and the ladies who work for her. It’s also a portrait that illustrates everything it takes for Black women, especially immigrants, to survive in this country. Amid the sacrifices and the tears, the play showcases the community these women build among themselves and how they care for each other when no one else will.”

criticReviews.author: Peter Marks
criticReviews.excerpt:
"“This bittersweet facet of the play seems to be token Bioh’s not-so-sunny perspective, which emerges as the 95 minutes of ‘Jaja’s’ wind down, when she introduces a harsher reality...You sense in her fate the dramatist’s anger, as she pulls the rug of joy out from under ‘Jaja’s’ and forces us to confront a colder truth about the dangers immigrants face. The customers’ braids may hold, it seems, even when the braider’s life unravels.”
"

criticReviews.author: Peter Marks
criticReviews.excerpt: “Writing what you know works out wonderfully well for playwright Jocelyn Bioh in ‘Jaja’s African Hair Braiding,’ a sparkling ensemble comedy as tautly woven as one of the intricate hairdos in Jaja’s Harlem salon...The playwright does at the end of this wickedly entertaining evening give in to the urge to highlight her characters’ plights a bit too baldly.”

criticReviews.author: Emlyn Travis
criticReviews.excerpt: “There are no easy answers to the complex problems that ‘Jaja's African Hair Braiding’ presents, and certainly none that can be solved within the span of a single day. Instead, the play encourages viewers to inspect the way the current world works and, hopefully, leave its salon with a greater sense of compassion and understanding for those around them tirelessly working to make ends meet.”

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: CRITIC’S PICK: “The real giveaway, though, is the compulsive ingratiation. Though it produces much laughter, including too many giggles from the comic himself, the doggy overeagerness could stand to be toned down”

criticReviews.author: Joe Dziemianowicz
criticReviews.excerpt: “Edelman does the all spinning here as he displays his irresistible gift for storytelling, comedy, and capturing theatregoers’ undivided attention...Count me in as an instant admirer.”

criticReviews.author: Raven Snook
criticReviews.excerpt: “The laughs are plentiful. Despite the incendiary issues lurking at the edges of his tale, ‘Just for Us’ is more focused on comedy than catharsis. Edelman is a master of callbacks, and his funniest jokes are accented with wonderful bulging eyes.”

criticReviews.author: Jackson McHenry
criticReviews.excerpt: “Like the stools, Edelman’s sometimes shaggy material is laid out intentionally. He’s a people-pleaser as a comedian, and he admits in the show that he’s holding back potentially alienating aspects of himself in order to win us over. To a much more extreme degree, he was also performing to ingratiate himself among the white nationalists.”

criticReviews.author: Greg Evans
criticReviews.excerpt: "Among the teachings of his Jewish upbringing is empathy, and even sitting outnumbered in that racist, antisemitic gathering he struggles to remain true to those values. That struggle provides Edelman with a mighty intellectual conundrum, a worthy and funny debate of the heart and a show that can stand proud on Broadway."

criticReviews.author: Chris Jones
criticReviews.excerpt: “Silly, sure, but humanizing at the same time.”

criticReviews.author: Naveen Kumar
criticReviews.excerpt: “Treating tough truths with quick humor would seem like another defining feature of Edelman’s inheritance.”

criticReviews.author: David Cote
criticReviews.excerpt: “...the production, directed by the late Adam Brace, is exceptionally tight, the material tweaked and buffed to gleaming perfection, with the 34-year-old comedian bopping around the stage using a trio of stools to conjure up multiple locations and figures”

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: "...McAdams’s natural sunniness and Mary Jane’s reality enhances the play’s tension."

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: "...McAdams’s natural sunniness and Mary Jane’s reality enhances the play’s tension."

criticReviews.author: Joe Dziemianowicz
criticReviews.excerpt: "Rachel McAdams soars in poignant slice-of-life play"

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: "...Herzog’s play shines like a candle in the dark."

criticReviews.author: Jackson McHenry
criticReviews.excerpt: "McAdams works in ways that tend toward the understated, yet precisely observed."

criticReviews.author: Aramide Tinubu
criticReviews.excerpt: “ 'Mary Jane' stays with viewers long after they leave the theater. "

criticReviews.author: Christian Lewis
criticReviews.excerpt: "It’s difficult to sit through, and yet, there is something consoling about it."

criticReviews.author: David Barbour
criticReviews.excerpt: "a portrait of an everyday saint, and a compelling one to boot."

criticReviews.author: Alexis Soloski
criticReviews.excerpt: “Mother Play is a quieter show, softer and less shattering."

criticReviews.author: Allison Considine
criticReviews.excerpt: "Mother Play is all about the mother’s touch and what it means to mother and be mothered"

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: "While Mother Play may be punitive, it is never pitilessly so."

criticReviews.author: Jackson McHenry
criticReviews.excerpt: "Her script assembles the contradictions...but it doesn’t provide a route through them."

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: "...a funny and affecting but slight and fragmentary drama depicting Ms. Lange’s Phyllis"

criticReviews.author: Aramide Tinubu
criticReviews.excerpt: "...a genuinely engaging examination of a family trying to find equilibrium."

criticReviews.author: Christian Holub
criticReviews.excerpt: "...Vogel’s latest hits the emotional beats...reminder to call your mom now and then."

criticReviews.author: Rachel Graham
criticReviews.excerpt: "...ends exactly as expected, but the emotional rollercoaster is worth the ride."

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: "“Patriots” is a wild story of makers switching places"

criticReviews.author: Kyle Turner
criticReviews.excerpt: "It’s an easily digestible version of history"

criticReviews.author: Raven Snook
criticReviews.excerpt: 3/5 Stars. The play's not the thing here...Stuhlbarg and Keen are the crème de la Kremlin.

criticReviews.author: Sara Holdren
criticReviews.excerpt: "Morgan’s work is thinky, at times witty and always distanced from judgment."

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: "...Peter Morgan’s intelligent historical drama."

criticReviews.author: Chris Jones
criticReviews.excerpt: "'Patriots,' a gripping, juicy drama replete with a terrifying performance"

criticReviews.author: Frank Rizzo
criticReviews.excerpt: "...characters are broadly outlined, psychologically shallow and simplistically played."

criticReviews.author: Naveen Kumar
criticReviews.excerpt: "...most gripping when it delivers...the inner workings of a burgeoning mastermind"

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: “What is too much for the world is way too much for the play. And the play, for all its urgency, is already way too much. Running just over three hours, ‘Prayer for the French Republic,’...is still not long enough to do justice to the multiple histories it wants to tell.”

criticReviews.author: Joe Dziemianowicz
criticReviews.excerpt: “It’s a plus-size play about big social issues that impresses in large structural ways as well as small moments...so this ‘Prayer’ will likely always be relevant. That’s a dramatic triumph – and a scorching reality.”

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: “There is perceptiveness and humor in ‘Prayer for the French Republic,’ and Cromer’s direction does its best to keep things honest. But as Harmon weighs out the issues, you can sense his thumb on the scale; by the denouement, it feels more like his whole hand, pressing for amens.”

criticReviews.author: Sara Holdren
criticReviews.excerpt: “Though it’s surrounded by heavy clouds, Harmon’s play is plenty sharp and by no means gloomy...How much you respond to ‘Prayer’ may ultimately rest on your taste for such harangues. I admit to finding them hard to follow — not intellectually but emotionally. They leave me cold and a little suspicious.”

criticReviews.author: Helen Shaw
criticReviews.excerpt: “Like any play transferring to Broadway from an Off Broadway success, this ‘Prayer’ is a counterproposal to its earlier, smaller, and more intimate iteration.”

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: “ 'Prayer for the French Republic' addresses, with nuance, detail and understated passion, the tensions and the connections between history and current events."

criticReviews.author: Greg Evans
criticReviews.excerpt: “...Edwards and his castmates bring two distinct, if not always so dissimilar, eras to life, and they tell a sweeping story while conveying genuine intimacy. ‘Prayer for the French Republic’ asks big questions – of history, of family, of identity – and, all but miraculously, answers their call.”

criticReviews.author: Chris Jones
criticReviews.excerpt: “The play, narrated uneasily by the self-doubting Patrick, is saying that little has been solved, the Jew remains a wanderer by necessity, that the painful lessons of history have never been more important, and love and happiness must be grabbed where it can.”

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: “...though ‘The Cottage’ operates like a farce it only rarely achieves a farce’s liftoff. That’s when the pressure on the characters becomes so intense that it initiates a kind of verbal and physical fission.”

criticReviews.author: Joe Dziemianowicz
criticReviews.excerpt: “ ‘The Cottage’ is about Sylvia opening her eyes to her relationships with men. But the moment that sticks out is the hilarious sight of Sylvia plugging her nose with an old-timey phone receiver. Moments like that make ‘The Cottage’ a Broadway funhouse.”

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: "While the architecture of the plot is solid, what really keeps 'The Cottage' up is the comedic industry of its cast. Directed by Jason Alexander, a seasoned hand at classic timing, the actors leap gamely into their funny business."

criticReviews.author: Jackson McHenry
criticReviews.excerpt: “There’s a fizz that bubbles up near the end of a door-slamming farce when the characters, one by one, have to explain to one another what’s actually going on...’The Cottage' tries to emphasize the fizz, but nobody remembered to shake the soda can beforehand. It’s full of explanations, light on mess.”

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: "Given the year the play is set, these developments seem more a matter of pandering to contemporary ideas than anything else. But linear logic is not a hallmark of farce, good, bad or, as in this case, indifferent."

criticReviews.author: Chris Jones
criticReviews.excerpt: “Just check with everyone in your group: Some will be tickled pink by ‘The Cottage’ and thrill to the très outré comic stylings...Others will be ready to head to the basement bar at intermission to nurse their headache and remain there...All that said, given the givens, I still had several good laughs.”

criticReviews.author: Naveen Kumar
criticReviews.excerpt: “...this comedy of manners by the playwright Sandy Ruskin is so thoroughly old-fashioned that it may come as a surprise it’s not based — like so many Broadway outings lately are — on existing material. Which is not to say that any part of it feels original.”

criticReviews.author: Rex Reed
criticReviews.excerpt: “The best thing about ‘The Cottage’ is the cottage, designed by someone with the name Paul Tate dePoo III. Everything else is more like the outhouse. Even as a lark, it’s beneath the standards of Broadway.”

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: “...details do not on their own create much dramatic interest. Plots consisting of hurry-up-and-wait rarely do. Were it not for its curious meta-story, the play would be little more than a pleasant diversion: 95 minutes of bloodless, toothless, Hollywood-adjacent dramedy.”

criticReviews.author: Joe Dziemianowicz
criticReviews.excerpt: “ ‘The Shark Is Broken’ is all talk, and a pattern emerges. Shaw and Dreyfuss clash. Scheider referees. It gets repetitive over the 95-minute run time. On the plus side, there are moments when the warring trio clicks and a sort of camaraderie shines through. Plus, the co-authors seasoned the script with laughs.”

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: “For a play that draws much of its appeal from nostalgia, ’The Shark Is Broken’ mostly avoids documentary-style exposition about the making of Jaws...In any case, the play has the good sense to end with Shaw’s performance of that very speech—which the actor also had a hand in writing—in its entirety. Intense and lean, it handily outmatches the preceding scenes of uneasy boatmates bobbing in the drink.”

criticReviews.author: Jackson McHenry
criticReviews.excerpt: “Fathers end up being ‘The Shark Is Broken’s’ primary way into its whole central trio...The scene in the latter half of the one act where the three of them start to open up about their fathers hits at something emotionally where the rest of the play tends to be too stuffed with trivia...It’s where the actors’ performances cool off from nervous, meticulous imitation into a truer dynamic.”

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: “ ‘The Shark Is Broken’ is not a play for the ages, or even for those who have never seen ‘Jaws,’ but it’s a frisky and continuously amusing diversion—perfect late-summer entertainment if you want to stay away from the ocean.”

criticReviews.author: Greg Evans
criticReviews.excerpt: “Beyond its good will and nostalgic conjuring, ’The Shark Is Broken’ is too slender a tale, too gentle, to provide thrills or even, truth be told, much drama.”

criticReviews.author: New York Daily News
criticReviews.excerpt: “In the end, there’s not a lot here: No crazy shark puppets, little sense of the raging seas nor of tormented, insecure actors — not much for the eye to see and very little happening that you don’t anticipate just five or 10 minutes into the show.”

criticReviews.author: Trish Deitch
criticReviews.excerpt: “This might have been a fascinating portrait of male ego and insecurity, with real insights into the workings of Hollywood in the 1970s...But written by the son of the late Robert Shaw, the piece feels like artless autobiography or maybe even a son’s revenge.”

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: "...a bitter satire of local politics that soon reveals itself as a slow-boil tragedy"

criticReviews.author: Allison Considine
criticReviews.excerpt: "Gold's production...skillfully balances the play’s history and its timeliness."

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: "Gold’s 'An Enemy of the People'... feels pointedly modern"

criticReviews.author: Sara Holdren
criticReviews.excerpt: "Strong and Imperioli both bring a vigorous contemporary affect to the material."

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: "...performed in a supremely intelligent new version by Amy Herzog."

criticReviews.author: Daniel D'Addario
criticReviews.excerpt: "An actorly, Broadway face-off between Jeremy Strong and Michael Imperioli"

criticReviews.author: David Rooney
criticReviews.excerpt: "the new production deftly underscores the parallels of our current ugly political divide"

criticReviews.author: Naveen Kumar
criticReviews.excerpt: "Climate activists disrupting Jeremy Strong was the best part of the play"

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: CRITIC’S PICK: “...Neugebauer’s direction, which is so smart and swift for most of the play’s substantial length that you feel gripped by storytelling without being strangled by argument.”

criticReviews.author: Allison Considine
criticReviews.excerpt: “The sound design, by Bray Poor and Will Pickens, transports audiences into the sweltering discomfort of the South with the overpowering sound of the cicadas that continue throughout the show. ‘Appropriate’ is well worth the buzz.”

criticReviews.author: Sara Holdren
criticReviews.excerpt: “Neugebauer is doing fine work with the whole ensemble, and Paulson and Stoll provide a supercharged core.”

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: "This being a drama firmly grounded in the hallowed miserable-American-family tradition, by the conclusion all the secrets have tumbled out, and the ugly bones of long-held resentments have been picked over. And over, and over—the play runs nearly three hours."

criticReviews.author: Greg Evans
criticReviews.excerpt: “...’Appropriate’ provides an ending that’s remarkable in its emotional force and stunning in its stagecraft. Neugebauer, Jacobs-Jenkins and their very fine cast resurrect the spirits of history and leave them abandoned, clamorous, implacable and going nowhere anytime soon.”

criticReviews.author: Aramide Tinubu
criticReviews.excerpt: “The story holds together with incredible performances from the entire cast...Racist histories and artifacts are appalling, of course, but it’s the unwillingness to discuss the past that allows these prejudices to fester across generations. These beliefs not only continue to suffocate us as a society but are also wreaking havoc on the lives of families like the Lafayettes every day.”

criticReviews.author: Lovia Gyarkye
criticReviews.excerpt: “...funny and sophisticated. The jokes are biting and some lines are impressively abrasive. But it edges away from the satire. Neugebauer’s fine direction instead leans into the acid drama of fraught sibling relationships. The play treats each character’s plight with an earnest consideration. There’s a more reflective, tragicomic stance as it considers what happens to families afraid to confront the past.”

criticReviews.author: David Cote
criticReviews.excerpt: “Clearly relishing their juicy roles, the dream cast has been impeccably directed by Lila Neugebauer, who burnishes the comedy and cruelty to a bright sheen. Her production would not cohere and hurtle as it does without its superbly unified design.”

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: "Like procedurals, it withholds information to maintain suspense"

criticReviews.author: Gillian Russo
criticReviews.excerpt: "Those sensitive to issues of sexual and child abuse may have some difficulty with Doubt."

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: " 'Doubt' is an odd kind of mystery, less a whodunit than a wasitdunatall."

criticReviews.author: Sara Holdren
criticReviews.excerpt: "...Doubt is still a sharp and sturdy piece of writing."

criticReviews.author: Vinson Cunningham
criticReviews.excerpt: "At its best, 'Doubt' is about formality."

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: "...Ryan and Schreiber, presents the play without any intentional new slant on its ideas"

criticReviews.author: Chris Jones
criticReviews.excerpt: "...a timely and now seemingly timeless piece of art that shed light"

criticReviews.author: Aramide Tinubu
criticReviews.excerpt: "Liev Schreiber’s performance cuts through a somber and confining single act"

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: "Sleek, lucid, amusing...it’s Chekhov with everything, except the main thing."

criticReviews.author: Joe Dziemianowicz
criticReviews.excerpt: "Steve Carell brings his comic chops to a dramatic classic"

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: Schreck’s lively and attentive translation cleverly retains as much of Chekhov’s language

criticReviews.author: Sara Holdren
criticReviews.excerpt: "Intertwined issues of script, casting, and direction are at work here."

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: "...both cast and staging struggle to cohere."

criticReviews.author: Trish Deitch
criticReviews.excerpt: "Steve Carell fits seamlessly into a stellar ensemble in a gorgeous broadway revival"

criticReviews.author: Johnny Oleksinski
criticReviews.excerpt: "...the actor’s [Steve Carell] presence gets laughs before he does much of anything."

criticReviews.author: Shania Russell
criticReviews.excerpt: "This update on Vanya doesn’t alter the story in any revolutionary terms"

criticReviews.author: Jonathan Mandell
criticReviews.excerpt: If you know what to expect, the show is sufficiently entertaining [but it is] not ambitious theater, nor is it even really about ambition. Although some of Simon Rich’s individual stories are inherently theatrical, the selection overall feels random.

criticReviews.author: Laura Collins-Hughes
criticReviews.excerpt: "it is a bouncy, crowd-pleasing comedy about female empowerment, self-acceptance and chasing one’s ambitions."

criticReviews.author: Kyle Turner
criticReviews.excerpt: "...it’s curious that, particularly in today's political environment, the show loops back to a relatively unquestioned idea about the meaning, value, and reality of the American dream."

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: "This show is a bona fide crowd pleaser: a warm hug that pulls you into its generous bosom. With a little luck, it could turn out to be a sleeper hit."

criticReviews.author: Greg Evans
criticReviews.excerpt: "funny, tender, compassionate and so well-performed by the eight women on stage that it earned a mid-show standing ovation the night I was in attendance."

criticReviews.author: Frank Rizzo
criticReviews.excerpt: "It’s a joyous scene of empowerment, with the women taking prideful ownership of their bodies, their lives and the stage."

criticReviews.author: Meg Masseron
criticReviews.excerpt: "Real Women Have Curves offers far more than just its body-positive title. It may not be the flashiest musical of the season, but it’s real."

criticReviews.author: Kimberly Ramirez
criticReviews.excerpt: "The show pulses with a distinctly chingona spirit–it is bold and defiantly optimistic despite relentlessly biased"

criticReviews.author: Victor Gluck
criticReviews.excerpt: Not only a joyous entertainment, it is also a moving tribute to the immigrant experience.

criticReviews.author: Jesse Green
criticReviews.excerpt: "the tree...onstage is among the most beautiful and wondrous theatrical creations"

criticReviews.author: Gillian Russo
criticReviews.excerpt: "Redwood...like the redwood tree, as we learn, its roots remain shallow."

criticReviews.author: Adam Feldman
criticReviews.excerpt: "The show is all bark and no bite. "

criticReviews.author: Sara Holdren
criticReviews.excerpt: "for all its soaring vocals and vertical movement, Redwood leaves us stubbornly grounded."

criticReviews.author: Charles Isherwood
criticReviews.excerpt: "They wrap the show in visually alluring wallpaper. "

criticReviews.author: Frank Rizzo
criticReviews.excerpt: "...you could call “Redwood” a musical chamber piece with monumentality"

criticReviews.author: David Cote
criticReviews.excerpt: "You want to leave shivering with the majesty of nature"

criticReviews.author: Naveen Kumar
criticReviews.excerpt: "...the moral of the story make you want to go outside and touch grass"
